channel.title: Guitar
channel.description:
I've been playing guitar for a few years now and I've hit a bit of a roadblock. To give you an idea of where I'm at, I play mostly Christian rock, both [url=http://www.ibanez.com/ElectricGuitars/model-RG350EX]electric[/url] and [url=http://www.fender.com/products/search.php?partno=0961405021]acoustic[/url]. I'm a lazy learner, so I pick up techniques while learning a song, I don't do drills. That said, I can pick and strum fairly well, and I've dabbled in fingerpicking, hybrid picking, and tapping.
I'd like to learn different chord shapes and improv, but honestly, I don't know where to start. I also want to listen to more guitar, but the only song I like by a good guitarist is Angelina by Tommy Emmanuel. Any other aspiring guitarists out there with tips?

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @Syfal Syfal
item.description:
@Syfal wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:10, topic:367055”]You need a deeper understanding of music theory to improve beyond what you’re doing now.

Like PaulT said, learn your scales. Start with ionian (major) and work your way through the modes, learn pentatonic, and minor pentatonic (blues scale). The nice thing about guitar is once you learn it in one key you know it in all keys. Learn how chords are constructed based on the degrees of these scales. Work on reading music. Learn about key signatures (goes hand in hand with cycle of 5ths/4ths), different rhythms, the concept of comping and swing time.

Christian rock is generally pretty basic so you’re going to have to branch out a bit if you really want to be a well rounded guitarist.

the relative minor seventh.

What do you mean by this? The relative minor is the sixth, which could technically be a minor dominant seventh I guess…[/quote]

Good advice. Learn your scales, especially the modes; they include all other minor scales, and Spanish scales (Lydian). Try listening to some good guitarists, this will help you find your own style of playing; try Eric Clapton, Brian Carroll (Buckethead), Leadbelly, and some metal guitarists if you want to become insane at soloing.

As far as improv, the best way to learn it would be to find a jazz guitarist and learn from him/her. Don’t bother going into the really big jazz stuff like compound cadences unless you plan on playing jazz guitar.

Lastly, learn some basic theory, and then some more specific theory in your favorite area of music when you get the basics down.

Good luck

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:24, topic:367055”]only 3 months? :p[/quote]It’s actually a funny story. There is a story about a place known as the “Crossroads”, I’m not sure if you’ve heard it. Apparently, anyone that has been to the “Crossroads” has sold their soul to the devil in order to reach their place in fame and whatnot. Bob Dylan talks about it a few times. It’s a folk tale that follows a lot of blues players.

Everyone says Bob Dylan just sat in a room by himself for like 3 or 4 months though and played guitar nonstop until he perfected like 20 different artists guitar styles and that’s really how he got to play so well.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

Bob Dylan. He’s combined his style with like 5 different genres and hundreds of artists. Pretty sure he sat in a room alone with his guitar for about 3 months non stop practicing. Although you might not like his style of music, the guitar is amazing. A friend of mine was playing Don’t Think Twice It’s Alright and it was the best thing I’ve ever heard him play acoustic.

I’m an acoustic guy, and I love Mumford and Sons. Perhaps try a few folk songs.

Also, have you tried singing?

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yeah, I understand what you’re saying, I just never particularly found the layout of notes and “fingering patterns” hard parts of learning an instrument.

That said, I pretty much just play guitar and piano Perhaps it is a big deal on brass and stuff I haven’t played.

EDIT: Also, your simplification is not strictly strictly true, because when you’re dealing with fretboard instruments, yes ok the scales are easily transposable, but you can also play them in multiple ways. There are multiple E4’s, etc.

So if you’re going to stick with the idea of “patterns”, there are a ridiculous amount of different patterns per scale on the guitar (albeit only 4-5 practical ones)

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Mopman:

So you DID just mean learning the fretboard. You’re right then, I guess, but I don’t see it as a big enough part of learning an instrument to be a big deal

I can learn one scale on guitar and instantly be able to play it in every key. To do the same on trumpet would essentially require me to learn 11 other entirely different fingering patterns.

Just for comparison, most competent musicians would know at the very least the 7 modern modes plus say 3 more scales. A guitarist can memorize just those 10 patterns and be done with it, something easily accomplished in a week. For a trumpet player, they must learn 120 different patterns to be at the same level as the guitarist.

Will a trumpet player often be using an F# locrian scale? Probably not, but if you’re improvising and the chord construction happens to match it, you had better know it or be able to think of it in your head pretty damn fast.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Unhandled:

All stringed instruments. If I learn a C major scale on something like trumpet, saxophone or even piano I have to learn totally different fingerings for a D major scale etc, but on a guitar I just move everything up two frets.

So you DID just mean learning the fretboard. You’re right then, I guess, but I don’t see it as a big enough part of learning an instrument to be a big deal

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

You need a deeper understanding of music theory to improve beyond what you’re doing now.

Like PaulT said, learn your scales. Start with ionian (major) and work your way through the modes, learn pentatonic, and minor pentatonic (blues scale). The nice thing about guitar is once you learn it in one key you know it in all keys. Learn how chords are constructed based on the degrees of these scales. Work on reading music. Learn about key signatures (goes hand in hand with cycle of 5ths/4ths), different rhythms, the concept of comping and swing time.

Christian rock is generally pretty basic so you’re going to have to branch out a bit if you really want to be a well rounded guitarist.

PaulT:

the relative minor seventh.

What do you mean by this? The relative minor is the sixth, which could technically be a minor dominant seventh I guess…

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

If you want to play with other people or improvise, practice playing scales in rhythm and playing with the radio or CDs. It’s good to know some blues licks, too, make the guitar sing. The pentatonic scale, the blues scale, the gypsy jazz scale, etc… are all good to use. Learn about the circle of fifths and the relative minor seventh. Learn the E major shape barre chord and the A major shape barre chord, which can be moved around and easily modified into minor suspended seventh or ninth chords. Don’t play Christian music, it makes you look weak and stupid.

Read full topic
